sp.l: ¶Lo where he commeth at hand, belike he was not fare
Diccon heare be two or three, thy company can not spare.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ God blesse you, and you may be blest so many al at once

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: ¶ Come knaue, it were a good deed to geld the by cockes bones
Seest not thy handiwarke▪ sir Rat can ye forbeare him?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ A vēgeance on those hands lite, for my hāde cam not nere hym
The horsen priest hath lift the pot, in some of these alewyues chayres
That his head wolde not serue him, belyke
to come downe the stayres.

sp.speaker: Baily.
sp.l: ¶ Nay soft, thou maist not play ye knaue, & haue this language to
If thou thy tong bridle a while, the better maist thou do,
Confesse the truth as I shall aske, and cease a while to fable.
And for thy fault I promise the, thy handling shalbe reasonable
Hast thou not made a lie or two, to set these tw • by the eares?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ What if I haue▪ fiue hundred such
haue I seene within these seuen yeares:
I am sory for nothing else but that I see not the sport
Which was betwene them whē they met, as they thēselues report

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶ The greatest thing master rat, ye se how he is drest.

sp.speaker: Diccon.
sp.l: ¶ What deuil nede he be groping so depe, in good wife Chats hēs nest

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶ Yea but it was thy drift to bring him into y• briars.

sp.speaker: Diccon.
sp.l: ¶ Gods bread, hath not such an old foole, wit to saue his eares?
He showeth himselfe herein ye see, so very a coxe,
The Cat was not so madly alured by the Foxe,
To run into the snares, was set for him doubtlesse,
For he leapt in for myce, and this sir Iohn for madnes.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: ¶ Well and ye shift no better, ye losel, lyther, and la ••• ,
I will go neare for this, to make ye leape at a Dasye.
In the kings name master Bayly, I charge you set him fast.

sp.speaker: Diccon.
sp.l: ¶ What fast at cardes, or fast on slepe? it is the thing I did last.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: ¶ Nay fast in fetters false varlet, according to thy deedes.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶ Master doctor ther is no remedy, I must intreat you needes
Some other kinde of punishment,

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: ¶Nay by all Halowes.
His punishmēt if I may iudg, shalbe naught els but the gallous.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶ That were to sore, a spiritual man to be so extreame.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: ¶ Is he worthy any better, sir how do ye iudge and deame?

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶ I graunt him wortie punishment, but in no wise so great.

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ It is a shame ich tel you plaine, for such false knaues intreat
He has almost vndone vs al, that is as tr • e as steele▪
And yet for al this great a do'cham neuer the nere my neele.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶ Canst yu not say any thing to that diccon, wish least or most▪

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Yea mary sir, thus much I can say wel, the nedle is lost.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶ Nay canst not thou tel which way, that nedle may be found

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ No by my fay sir. though I might haue an hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Thou lier lickdis • , didst not say the neele wold be gitten?

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ No hodge, by the same token, you where that time be s • itten?
For feare of Hobgobling, you wot wel what I meane,
As long as it is sence, I feare me yet ye be scarce cleane.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶ Wel master rat, you must both learne, & teach vs to forgeue
Since Diccon hath confession made, • is so cleane shreue,
If ye to me conscent, to amend this heauie chaunce.
I wil inioyne him here, some open kind of penaunce:
Of this condition, where ye know my fee is twenty pence
For the bloodshed, I am agreed with you here to dispence,
Ye shal go quite, so that ye graunt, the matter now to run,
To end with mirth emong vs al, euen as it was begun.

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: ¶ Say yea master vicar, & he shal sure confes to be your dotter
And al we that be heare present, wil loue you much the better

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: ¶ My part is the worst, but since you al here on agree.
Go euen to master Bayly▪ let it be so for mee,

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶ How saiest thou diccon, art content this shal on me depend

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Go to M. Bayly say on your mind, I know ye are my frend▪

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶Then marke ye wel, to recompence this thy former action
Because thou hast offended al, to make them satisfaction,
Before their faces, here kneele downe, & as I shal the teach.
For thou shalt take on othe, of hodges leather breache
First for master Doctor, vpon paine of his cu • sse,
Where he wil pay for al▪ thou neuer draw thy pur •• e.
And when ye m • ete at one pot, he shall haue the first pull,
And thou shalt neuer offer him the cup, but it be full.
To good wife ch • t thou shalt be sworne, euen on the same wyse
If • he refuse thy money once, neuer to offer it twise.
Thou shalt be bound by the same here, as thou dost take it
When thou maist drinke of free cost, thou neuer forsake it:
For gammer gurtons sake, againe sworne shalt thou bee
To helpe hir to hir ne • le againe if it do lie in thee
And likewise be bound: by the vertue of that
To be of good abering to Gib hir great Cat:
Last of al for Hodge, the othe to scanne,
Thou shalt neuer take him, for fine gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Come on fellow Diccon chalbe euen with thee now.

sp.speaker: Bayly
sp.l: ¶ Thou wilt not sticke to do this Diccon I trow.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ No by my fathers skin, my hand downe I lay it?
Lo • e as I haue promised, I wil not denay it,
But Hodge take good heede now, thou do not beshite me.
And gaue him a good blow on the buttocke.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶Gogs hart thou false villaine dost thou bite me •

sp.speaker: Bayly
sp.l: ¶ What Hodge doth he hurt the or euer he begin.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ He thrust me into the buttocke, with a bodkin or a pin,
I saie Gammer, Gammer?

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ How now Hodge, how now:

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Gods ma • t Gammer gurton.

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Thou art mad ich trow.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Will you see the deuil Gammer.

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ The deuil sonne, god blesse vs.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Chould iche were hanged Gammer.

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Mary se ye might dresse vs.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ • haue it by the masse Gammer

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ What not my neele Hodge?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶Your Neele Gammer, your neele.

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ No fie, dost but dodge.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Cha • ound • our neele Gammer, here in my hand be it.

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ For al the loues on earth Hodge, let me see it.

sp.speaker: Ho • ge
sp.l: ¶ Soft Gammer.

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Good Hodge.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Soft ich say, tarie a while.

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Nay swee • e Hodge say truth, and do not me begile.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Cham sure on it ich warrant you: it goes no more a stray

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Hodge when I speake so faire: wilt stil say me na • :

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Go neare the • ight gammer this wel in faith good lucke:
Chwas almost vndone: twas so far in my buttocke

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Tis min owne deare neele Hodge, sykerly I wot

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Cham I not a good sonne gammer, cham I not,

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Christs blessing light on thee, hast made me for euer

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Ich knew that ich must finde it, els choud a had it neuer

sp.speaker: Chat.
sp.l: ¶ By my troth Go •• py gurton, I am euen as glad
As though I mine owne selfe as good a turne had:

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶And I by my concience, to see it so come forth,
Reioyce so much at it, 〈◊〉 three nedles be worth.

sp.speaker: D. Rat.
sp.l: ¶ I am no whit sory to see you so reioyce.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Nor I much the gladder for al this noyce:
Yet say gramercy Diccon, for springing of the game.

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Gramercy Diccon twenty times, • how glad cham,
If that chould do so much, your masterdome to come hether,
Master Rat, good wife Chat, and Diccon together:
Cha but one half peny, as far as iche know it,
And chil not rest this night, till ich bestow it.
If euer ye loue me, let vs go in and drinke.

sp.speaker: Bayly.
sp.l: ¶ I am content if the rest thinke as I thinke▪
Mas • er Rat it shalbe best for you if we so doo,
Then shall you warme you and dr •• se your self too.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Soft syrs, take vs with you, the company shalbe the more,
As proude coms behinde they say, as any goes before,
But now my good masters since we must be gone
And leaue you behinde vs, here all alone:
Since at our last ending, thus mery we bee,
For Gammer Gurtons nedle sake, let vs haue a plaudyti • .

div.p: Imprinted at London in Fleetestreate beneath the Conduite, at the signe of S. Iohn Euangelist, by Thomas Colwell. 1575.
